lessons.name: Nouns
lessons.explanation: Nouns are words that name people, places, things, or ideas. They can be singular or plural, countable or uncountable, proper or common.
lessons.example: cat, London, happiness, water

lessons.name: Pronouns
lessons.explanation: Pronouns are words that replace nouns in a sentence. Types include personal, possessive, reflexive, and more.
lessons.example: he, she, it, themselves, ours

lessons.name: Verbs
lessons.explanation: Verbs are words that show action or a state of being. Types include action, linking, and auxiliary verbs.
lessons.example: run, is, have, think

lessons.name: Adjectives
lessons.explanation: Adjectives describe or modify nouns. They can show quality, quantity, or comparison.
lessons.example: big, blue, happier, most beautiful

lessons.name: Adverbs
lessons.explanation: Adverbs modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs. They often describe how, when, or where something happens.
lessons.example: quickly, very, here, yesterday

lessons.name: Prepositions
lessons.explanation: Prepositions show the relationship between a noun (or pronoun) and other words in a sentence.
lessons.example: in, on, at, under, between

lessons.name: Conjunctions
lessons.explanation: Conjunctions connect words, phrases, or clauses.
lessons.example: and, but, or, because

lessons.name: Interjections
lessons.explanation: Interjections are words or phrases that express strong emotion or surprise.
lessons.example: Wow! Oh no! Ouch!

lessons.name: Subject, Verb, Object
lessons.explanation: Most English sentences follow the Subject-Verb-Object (SVO) order.
lessons.example: She (subject) eats (verb) apples (object).

quiz.question: What is the object in: 'Tom reads a book'?

lessons.name: Phrases and Clauses
lessons.explanation: A phrase is a group of words without a subject-verb pair. A clause has a subject and a verb.
lessons.example: Phrase: in the morning | Clause: She runs.

lessons.name: Simple Sentences
lessons.explanation: A simple sentence has one independent clause.
lessons.example: The dog barks.

lessons.name: Present Simple
lessons.explanation: Present simple tense is used for habits, facts, and general truths.
lessons.example: She walks to school.

quiz.question: Which sentence is in present simple?

lessons.name: Past Simple
lessons.explanation: Past simple tense is used for actions that happened in the past.
lessons.example: He played football yesterday.

quiz.question: Which word is in past simple?

lessons.name: Future Simple
lessons.explanation: Future simple tense is used for actions that will happen in the future.
lessons.example: They will visit Paris.

lessons.name: Articles (a, an, the)
lessons.explanation: Articles are words that define a noun as specific or unspecific.
lessons.example: a cat, an apple, the sun

lessons.name: Basic Punctuation
lessons.explanation: Punctuation marks are used to separate sentences and clarify meaning.
lessons.example: period (.), comma (,), question mark (?)

lessons.name: Present Continuous
lessons.explanation: Present continuous tense describes actions happening now.
lessons.example: She is reading a book.

lessons.name: Past Continuous
lessons.explanation: Past continuous tense describes actions that were ongoing in the past.
lessons.example: They were playing football.

lessons.name: Present Perfect
lessons.explanation: Present perfect tense connects past actions to the present.
lessons.example: I have finished my homework.

lessons.name: Past Perfect
lessons.explanation: Past perfect tense describes an action completed before another past action.
lessons.example: She had left before he arrived.

lessons.name: Future Continuous
lessons.explanation: Future continuous tense describes actions that will be ongoing in the future.
lessons.example: They will be traveling tomorrow.

lessons.name: Modal Verbs
lessons.explanation: Modal verbs express ability, possibility, permission, or obligation.
lessons.example: can, could, may, might, must, shall, should, will, would

lessons.name: Conditionals (Zero, First, Second)
lessons.explanation: Conditionals describe possible or imaginary situations. Zero: always true. First: real future. Second: unreal present/future.
lessons.example: If it rains, we get wet. (Zero) | If it rains, we will stay home. (First) | If I were you, I would study. (Second)

quiz.question: Which is a first conditional?
options: If it rains, we get wet.
If I were you, I would study.
If it rains, we will stay home.
If I had known, I would have come.

lessons.name: Passive Voice
lessons.explanation: In passive voice, the subject receives the action.
lessons.example: The cake was eaten by Tom.

quiz.question: Which sentence is passive?
options: The cake was eaten by Tom.

lessons.name: Relative Clauses
lessons.explanation: Relative clauses give more information about a noun. They often start with who, which, or that.
lessons.example: The girl who sings is my sister.

quiz.question: Which word introduces a relative clause?

lessons.name: Compound Sentences
lessons.explanation: Compound sentences have two independent clauses joined by a conjunction.
lessons.example: I wanted to go, but it was raining.

quiz.question: Which is a compound sentence?
options: Because it was raining, I went home.
I wanted to go, but it was raining.

lessons.name: Complex Sentences
lessons.explanation: Complex sentences have one independent clause and at least one dependent clause.
lessons.example: Because it was raining, I stayed inside.

quiz.question: Which is a complex sentence?
options: Because it was raining, I stayed inside.

lessons.name: Subject-Verb Agreement
lessons.explanation: The verb must agree in number with its subject.
lessons.example: She walks. They walk.

lessons.name: Determiners
lessons.explanation: Determiners come before nouns to clarify what you are talking about.
lessons.example: this, that, these, those, my, your

lessons.name: Quantifiers
lessons.explanation: Quantifiers express quantity or amount.
lessons.example: some, any, many, few, much, little

lessons.name: Comparatives and Superlatives
lessons.explanation: Comparatives compare two things; superlatives compare more than two.
lessons.example: bigger, more beautiful, the biggest, the most beautiful

lessons.name: Reported Speech
lessons.explanation: Reported speech is used to tell what someone else said.
lessons.example: She said that she was tired.

quiz.question: Which is reported speech?
options: She said that she was tired.

lessons.name: Gerunds and Infinitives
lessons.explanation: A gerund is a verb ending in -ing used as a noun. An infinitive is 'to' + base verb.
lessons.example: Swimming is fun. I want to swim.

lessons.name: Present Perfect Continuous
lessons.explanation: This tense shows an action that started in the past and is still continuing.
lessons.example: She has been studying for two hours.

lessons.name: Past Perfect Continuous
lessons.explanation: This tense shows an action that was ongoing in the past before another past action.
lessons.example: He had been working before the rain started.

lessons.name: Future Perfect
lessons.explanation: This tense shows an action that will be completed before a certain future time.
lessons.example: She will have finished by noon.

lessons.name: Conditionals (Third, Mixed)
lessons.explanation: Third conditional is for unreal past. Mixed conditional is for past condition with present result.
lessons.example: If I had known, I would have come. (Third) | If I had studied, I would be rich. (Mixed)

quiz.question: Which is a third conditional?
options: If it rains, we get wet.
If I had known, I would have come.
If it rains, we will stay home.
If I were you, I would study.

lessons.name: Subjunctive Mood
lessons.explanation: The subjunctive is used to express wishes, suggestions, or hypothetical situations.
lessons.example: If I were you, I would go.

quiz.question: Which sentence uses the subjunctive?
options: If I were you, I would go.

lessons.name: Inversion
lessons.explanation: Inversion is changing the normal word order, often for emphasis or in questions.
lessons.example: Never have I seen such beauty.

quiz.question: Which sentence uses inversion?
options: I have never seen such beauty.
Never have I seen such beauty.

lessons.name: Noun Clauses
lessons.explanation: A noun clause acts as a noun in a sentence.
lessons.example: What you said is true.

lessons.name: Adverbial Clauses
lessons.explanation: Adverbial clauses modify verbs, adjectives, or adverbs and answer questions like when, where, why, or how.
lessons.example: I will call you when I arrive.

lessons.name: Reduced Clauses
lessons.explanation: Reduced clauses are shorter forms of dependent clauses.
lessons.example: While driving, she listened to music. (Instead of: While she was driving...)

quiz.question: Which is a reduced clause?
options: While driving, she listened to music.

lessons.name: Participle Clauses
lessons.explanation: Participle clauses use present or past participles to shorten sentences.
lessons.example: Feeling tired, he went to bed.

quiz.question: Which is a participle clause?
options: Feeling tired, he went to bed.

lessons.name: Causatives
lessons.explanation: Causatives show that someone causes another person to do something.
lessons.example: She had her car washed.

lessons.name: Ellipsis
lessons.explanation: Ellipsis is leaving out words that are understood from context.
lessons.example: She can play the guitar, and he can too. (play the guitar is omitted)

quiz.question: Which sentence uses ellipsis?
options: She can play the guitar, and he can too.

lessons.name: Correlative Conjunctions
lessons.explanation: Correlative conjunctions are pairs of conjunctions that work together.
lessons.example: either...or, neither...nor, both...and

lessons.name: Advanced Prepositions
lessons.explanation: Advanced prepositions cover more complex relationships and usage.
lessons.example: according to, in spite of, on behalf of

lessons.name: Phrasal Verbs
lessons.explanation: Phrasal verbs are verbs combined with prepositions or adverbs.
lessons.example: give up, look after, run into

lessons.name: Idioms and Expressions
lessons.explanation: Idioms are phrases with meanings different from their individual words.
lessons.example: It's raining cats and dogs.

lessons.name: Advanced Punctuation
lessons.explanation: Advanced punctuation includes dashes, parentheses, and more.
lessons.example: He went to the store â€“ and bought milk. (dash)

quiz.question: Which is an advanced punctuation mark?
